recentPerformance.last3Games: 46 pts vs PHI, 37 vs ATL, 35 vs DET

keyFactors.title: Recent 46-Point Explosion
keyFactors.description: Just erupted for season-high 46 points on 15-21 shooting (71.4% FG) vs Philadelphia 2 days earlier (Nov 5). Marked his 20th career 40-point game with Cleveland.

keyFactors.title: Elite Scoring Form
keyFactors.description: Scored 35+ in three consecutive games before PHI game. Averaging ridiculous 57.6% FG, 45.5% from three on the season.

keyFactors.title: Dream Matchup
keyFactors.description: Washington ranked 29th in defensive rating (119.1), dead last allowing 130.3 PPG (30th). Entered 1-7 on six-game losing streak with historically poor perimeter defense.

keyFactors.title: High-Tempo Game
keyFactors.description: Both teams ranked top-5 in tempo. Projected 241.5 total suggested high-possession game with ample scoring opportunities. Dimers.com projected Mitchell at 28 points.

riskFactors: Darius Garland's return (2nd game back from toe surgery) might distribute usage

quarterBreakdown.description: Cleveland jumped ahead early and never looked back. Led 76-59 at halftime - already massive 17-point advantage. Mitchell scored efficiently but game script was set.
Cavs extended to 109-86 after three quarters (23-point lead). Mitchell continued efficiency but minutes management began.
Pulled early as bench dominated garbage time. Tyrese Proctor (17 pts career-high), Sam Merrill (14 pts, 4-5 from three) absorbed fourth quarter minutes.

gameResults.whenMissed: Missing 7-8 minutes cost approximately 6-8 points. At his scoring rate, would have easily cleared 26.5 with normal minutes.
gameResults.gamePace: 262 total points (crushed projected 241.5 by 20.5). Cleveland shot 47.3% as team, 20-45 from three (44.4%). Final score: 148-114 blowout.
gameResults.foulTrouble: Zero fouls - no foul trouble. Simply pulled due to blowout.

whatWentWrong.title: 34-Point Blowout Robbed Minutes
whatWentWrong.description: Played only 26 minutes vs 33.9 season average. Missing 8 minutes cost 6-8 points at his per-36 pace of ~33 points. Game was over by mid-third quarter.

whatWentWrong.title: Balanced Attack
whatWentWrong.description: Garland (20 pts, 9 ast), Mobley (18 pts, 10 reb), Allen (16 pts, 14 reb) meant Mitchell didn't need to carry load. Depth dominated garbage time.

whatWentWrong.title: Too Efficient for Own Good
whatWentWrong.description: Team shot so well (47.3% FG, 44.4% from three) that game became non-competitive. Ironically, the dream matchup created a nightmare scenario.

whatWentWrong.title: Cruel Timing
whatWentWrong.description: Came 2 days after 46-point explosion, highlighting volatility of player props and unpredictability of blowouts.

statisticalContext.percentileRanking: Bottom 30th percentile when adjusted for minutes - actually on pace for ~33 points per 36

postGameAnalysis.wasNormalVariance: No - pure game script. Per-36 minute pace extrapolated to ~33 points, well over prop. Lost solely due to blowout minute reduction, not performance.

closingLineValue.verdict: Neutral CLV. Market accurately priced Mitchell's scoring potential. No one predicted 34-point blowout that would bench starters entire Q4.

keyTakeaways: Blowouts are the ultimate enemy of star player props - no amount of analysis predicts 34-point victories
When team shoots 47%/44% from three, stars sit early. Efficiency paradox.
Dream matchups (29th defense, 130 PPG allowed) can backfire via blowouts
Per-minute production was on pace (~33 points per 36), but missing 8 minutes fatal
Impossible to predict when elite scorers will be benched due to game flow
verdict: Classic 'bad beat.' Every pre-game metric screamed OVER - 31.9 PPG average, 46 points 2 days prior, facing worst defense in NBA. Lost purely to unpredictable blowout. Right process, cruel outcome.
